trans-unit.source: Converting WDK 8.1 Projects to WDK 10
trans-unit.target: Converting WDK 8.1 Projects to WDK 10

trans-unit.source: This topic describes how to convert a driver project that was created using Microsoft Visual Studio 2013 and Windows Driver Kit (WDK) 8.1 to a driver project that builds in Microsoft Visual Studio 2015 with the Windows Driver Kit (WDK) 10.
trans-unit.target: This topic describes how to convert a driver project that was created using Microsoft Visual Studio 2013 and Windows Driver Kit (WDK) 8.1 to a driver project that builds in Microsoft Visual Studio 2015 with the Windows Driver Kit (WDK) 10.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2015 has new compiler warnings and errors.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2015 has new compiler warnings and errors.

trans-unit.source: Even if your driver project built with no errors in Visual Studio 2013, you might see errors when you build it in Visual Studio 2015.
trans-unit.target: Even if your driver project built with no errors in Visual Studio 2013, you might see errors when you build it in Visual Studio 2015.

trans-unit.source: Use these steps to convert the projects in a driver solution.
trans-unit.target: Use these steps to convert the projects in a driver solution.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio 2015, open the legacy driver solution.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio 2015, open the legacy driver solution.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio automatically runs ProjectUpgradeTool to convert the projects in this solution.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio automatically runs ProjectUpgradeTool to convert the projects in this solution.

trans-unit.source: You can also run this tool from the command line.
trans-unit.target: You can also run this tool from the command line.

trans-unit.source: By default, when you install the WDK, ProjectUpgradeTool.exe installs in Windows Kits\\10\\bin\\x86.
trans-unit.target: By default, when you install the WDK, ProjectUpgradeTool.exe installs in Windows Kits\\10\\bin\\x86.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio opens a **Review Solution Actions** dialog with the title **Upgrade VC++ Compiler and Libraries**.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio opens a **Review Solution Actions** dialog with the title **Upgrade VC++ Compiler and Libraries**.

trans-unit.source: Click **OK** and Visual Studio attempts to upgrade all projects in the solution.
trans-unit.target: Click **OK** and Visual Studio attempts to upgrade all projects in the solution.

trans-unit.source: If you see a **File Modification Detected** dialog, choose **Reload All**.
trans-unit.target: If you see a **File Modification Detected** dialog, choose **Reload All**.

trans-unit.source: In the Solution Explorer pane, right-click the driver project name and choose **Properties**.
trans-unit.target: In the Solution Explorer pane, right-click the driver project name and choose **Properties**.

trans-unit.source: Click the **Configuration Manager** button.
trans-unit.target: Click the **Configuration Manager** button.

trans-unit.source: In the **Active solution configuration** list, choose **<New...>**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Active solution configuration** list, choose **<New...>**.

trans-unit.source: Type a name and copy the settings from a Windows 8.1 project context.
trans-unit.target: Type a name and copy the settings from a Windows 8.1 project context.

trans-unit.source: Click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: Typically, the converted solution contains two configuration profiles, one for debug (testing) and one for release.
trans-unit.target: Typically, the converted solution contains two configuration profiles, one for debug (testing) and one for release.

trans-unit.source: To create a similar environment with WDK 10, simply choose **<New...>** twice.
trans-unit.target: To create a similar environment with WDK 10, simply choose **<New...>** twice.

trans-unit.source: To create a debug profile, copy from the **Win 8.1 Debug** profile.
trans-unit.target: To create a debug profile, copy from the **Win 8.1 Debug** profile.

trans-unit.source: To create a release profile, copy from the **Win 8.1 Release** profile.
trans-unit.target: To create a release profile, copy from the **Win 8.1 Release** profile.

trans-unit.source: In WDK versions prior to WDK 10, your driver solution always needed a package project.
trans-unit.target: In WDK versions prior to WDK 10, your driver solution always needed a package project.

trans-unit.source: In WDK 10, you only need a package project if you are including multiple drivers in a driver package.
trans-unit.target: In WDK 10, you only need a package project if you are including multiple drivers in a driver package.

trans-unit.source: Use the following guidelines:
trans-unit.target: Use the following guidelines:

trans-unit.source: If you have only one driver in the solution and a package project exists, delete it.
trans-unit.target: If you have only one driver in the solution and a package project exists, delete it.

trans-unit.source: If you have more than one driver in the solution, ensure that your solution contains a package project.
trans-unit.target: If you have more than one driver in the solution, ensure that your solution contains a package project.

trans-unit.source: Then, for each driver project in the solution, open project properties and navigate to **Configuration Properties > Driver Settings**.
trans-unit.target: Then, for each driver project in the solution, open project properties and navigate to **Configuration Properties > Driver Settings**.

trans-unit.source: Set **BuildPackage** to **No**.
trans-unit.target: Set **BuildPackage** to **No**.

trans-unit.source: If you are building from the command line, set **/p:SupportsPackaging=false**.
trans-unit.target: If you are building from the command line, set **/p:SupportsPackaging=false**.

trans-unit.source: Again in driver project properties, choose **Properties**.
trans-unit.target: Again in driver project properties, choose **Properties**.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to **Configuration Properties > Driver Settings > General > Target OS Version**.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to **Configuration Properties > Driver Settings > General > Target OS Version**.

trans-unit.source: Select Windows 10.
trans-unit.target: Select Windows 10.

trans-unit.source: Verify that **Target Platform** is set to **Desktop**, and build the solution.
trans-unit.target: Verify that **Target Platform** is set to **Desktop**, and build the solution.

trans-unit.source: Fix any errors that occur.
trans-unit.target: Fix any errors that occur.

trans-unit.source: Once the solution builds successfully, change **Target Platform** to **Universal**.
trans-unit.target: Once the solution builds successfully, change **Target Platform** to **Universal**.

trans-unit.source: Build the solution again.
trans-unit.target: Build the solution again.

trans-unit.source: At this point, the only errors are from the ApiValidator tool, which checks if the driver calls any non-universal functionality.
trans-unit.target: At this point, the only errors are from the ApiValidator tool, which checks if the driver calls any non-universal functionality.

trans-unit.source: Replace any calls to non-universal DDIs with calls to universal DDIs.
trans-unit.target: Replace any calls to non-universal DDIs with calls to universal DDIs.

trans-unit.source: For more information about ApiValidator, see [Validating Universal Windows drivers](validating_universal_drivers.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information about ApiValidator, see [Validating Universal Windows drivers](validating_universal_drivers.md).

trans-unit.source: To learn how to determine the target platform for a given DDI, see [Target platform on MSDN driver reference pages](windows_10_editions_for_universal_drivers.md).
trans-unit.target: To learn how to determine the target platform for a given DDI, see [Target platform on MSDN driver reference pages](windows_10_editions_for_universal_drivers.md).
